user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of test_header:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
test_header (void *cls,
             const char *key,
             size_t key_size,
             const char *value,
             size_t value_size,
             enum MHD_ValueKind kind)
{
  struct test_header_param *const param = (struct test_header_param *) cls;
  struct MHD_Connection *connection = param->connection;
  struct MHD_HTTP_Req_Header *pos;
  size_t i;

  param->num_headers++;
  i = 0;
  for (pos = connection->rq.headers_received; NULL != pos; pos = pos->next)
  {
    if (kind != pos->kind)
      continue;
    if (++i == param->num_headers)
    {
      if (key_size != pos->header_size)
        return MHD_NO;
      if (value_size != pos->value_size)
        return MHD_NO;
      if (0 != key_size)
      {
        mhd_assert (NULL != key);
        mhd_assert (NULL != pos->header);
        if (0 != memcmp (key,
                         pos->header,
                         key_size))
          return MHD_NO;
      }
      if (0 != value_size)
      {
        mhd_assert (NULL != value);
        mhd_assert (NULL != pos->value);
        if (0 != memcmp (value,
                         pos->value,
                         value_size))
          return MHD_NO;
      }
      return MHD_YES;
    }
  }
  return MHD_NO;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
Fragments not listed above were not marked because there is no evidence in this snippet that they are statically unreachable. Specifically:
- The loop header and final "return MHD_NO;" are reachable depending on runtime data (connection->rq.headers_received and header kinds); no compile-time constant makes them impossible to execute.
- The conditional "if (kind != pos->kind) continue;" merely filters runtime cases and does not create a statically unreachable block.
- The memcmp calls and size comparisons are governed by runtime parameters (key_size, value_size, pos->header_size, pos->value_size) and thus cannot be proven unreachable from this snippet alone.
- The mhd_assert macros may be no-ops in some builds, but their presence does not by itself create unreachable code; they are runtime checks (or removed) rather than dead code introduced by the control flow.
- There are no statements after an unconditional return or infinite loop in the function body that would constitute statically unreachable code beyond the fragments listed.

The fragments reported above are places where control-flow may be effectively impossible under certain runtime or overflow conditions (e.g. the interaction of the pre-incremented param->num_headers and the ++i comparison, possible integer overflow of num_headers, or guards that may always be false in typical usage). These deserve closer inspection to determine whether any paths are actually unreachable in the project context.
